p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 27th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 15 May and 5 June 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 50 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 5509 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government impose sanctions on Israel (EN6141)
From 41 petitioners—requesting legislation to prohibit financial institutions from charging processing fees for bank card transactions (EN6142)
From 23 petitioners—requesting legislation to restrict social media access for children up to the age of 15 years old (EN6145)
From 25 petitioners—requesting Australian citizenship be offered to Muhammad Taha in acknowledgment of his bravery during the Westfield Bondi attack (EN6147)
From 7 petitioners—regarding pending charges being included in police checks (EN6148)
From 39 petitioners—regarding access to medical support for Australian Defence Force veterans (EN6151)
From 75 petitioners—requesting the repeal of the Online Safety Act 2021(EN6152)
From 2434 petitioners—requesting that an F/A-18 'Classic' Hornet be allocated to the Queensland Air Museum (EN6153)
From 11 petitioners—requesting that social work students be paid for work placements (EN6154)
From 31 petitioners—requesting universal free mental healthcare (EN6156)
From 43 petitioners—requesting more affordable mental healthcare (EN6157)
From 43 petitioners—requesting legislation to safeguard the role of cash in the Australian economy (EN6158)
From 12 petitioners—requesting the creation of an Australian Climate Corps initiative based on the United States model (EN6160)
From 1 petitioner—requesting that the Australian Government invest in the development of artificial intelligence (EN6161)
From 23 petitioners—requesting increased penalties for those found guilty of physical abuse towards persons with a disability (EN6162)
From 6 petitioners—requesting the development of a nuclear fusion energy industry in Australia (EN6163)
From 1 petitioner—requesting funding for the development of nuclear fusion maritime propulsion technology (EN6164)
From 3 petitioners—requesting funding for the development of nuclear fusion space propulsion technology (EN6165)
From 3 petitioners—requesting the development of a nuclear fusion energy industry in Australia (EN6166)
From 9 petitioners—requesting legislation to restrict social media access for children (EN6168)
From 249 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Constitution be amended to include protections for free speech (EN6169)
From 206 petitioners—requesting the investigation of Australian citizens who have fought for Hamas or served in the Israeli Defense Forces (EN6170)
From 552 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government impose sanctions on Israeli officials and business operating in the Occupied Palestinian Territories (EN6171)
From 32 petitioners—regarding the indexation rates applied to HECS-HELP loan debts (EN6172)
From 129813 petitioners—requesting that Australia formally recognise the state of Palestine (EN6173)
From 304 petitioners—regarding the importation of nicotine vaping products for personal use (EN6174)
From 2 petitioners—regarding the deportation of New Zealand citizens from Australia (EN6175)
From 4 petitioners—regarding the deportation of New Zealand citizens on character grounds (EN6176)
From 47 petitioners—regarding corporate tax obligations (EN6177)
From 51 petitioners—regarding the discontinuation of the pharmaceutical product Normacol Plus (EN6178)
From 56 petitioners—regarding public access to national parks (EN6179)
From 27 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government cancel United States Force Posture Initiatives related to the storage of nuclear material (EN6180)
From 20 petitioners—regarding eligibility for the Disability Support Pension for people living with vertigo and Meniere's disease (EN6182)
From 1 petitioner—requesting increased community safety measures (EN6183)
From 1 petitioner—requesting an inquiry into the Coffs Harbour Jetty Foreshore Precinct revitalisation project (EN6186)
From 23 petitioners—requesting the introduction of specific requirements for the sale of printers in Australia (EN6187)
From 3674 petitioners—requesting an increase to pay and allowances for Australian Federal Police officers and employees (EN6189)
From 48 petitioners—requesting the introduction of legislation to require genetic testing for child support claims (EN6190)
From 19 petitioners—requesting that privacy protections be established in relation to the use of images (EN6191)
From 6 petitioners—regarding the accessibility of portable haemodialysis machines (EN6192)
From 2648 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a royal commission into family violence (EN6193)
From 32 petitioners—requesting the cessation of automatic increases to fuel and alcohol excises (EN6197)
From 21298 petitioners—requesting a transition period for people affected by changes to age limits for Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) (EN6198)
From 51 petitioners—requesting the re-implementation of flight curfews in South Australia (EN6199)
From 2 petitioners—regarding post-natal psychiatric medications (EN6201)
From 27 petitioners—requesting early implementation of the Commonwealth Prac Payment scheme (EN6206)
From 258 petitioners—requesting that eligibility for the Commonwealth Prac Payment scheme be widened to include physiotherapy and occupational therapy students (EN6207)
From 545 petitioners—requesting legislation to facilitate involuntary mental health treatment for children (EN6209)
From 98 petitioners—regarding Australia's COVID-19 vaccination program (EN6210)
From 4007 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government commit further funding to humanitarian aid and support for Palestine (EN6212)

span.span: 2. The following 3 ministerial responses to petitions were
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 5 June 2024

p.span: From the Minister for Indigenous Australians to a petition regarding funding priorities within the Indigenous Australians portfolio (EN5070)
From the Minister for Climate Change and Energy to a petition requesting the cessation of all activities related to solar radiation management and geoengineering (EN5667)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a petition regarding the Veterans' Medicines Advice and Therapeutics Education Service program (EN5854)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, I present the following 50 petitions:
Gaza

A call to the Australian Government to end its complicity in the ongoing genocide in Palestine and impose trade and arms sanctions against Israel. On April 4th 2024, Israel deliberately killed aid workers leading to multiple aid organisations and charities to cease operations in Gaza. Since October 9th 2023, Gaza has been under a total blockade of food, fuel, electricity and water. The people of Gaza are already on the brink of starvation and urgently need international intervention to pressure Israel into ending its blockade and allow the unimpeded entry of aid into Gaza to prevent this man-made famine. We call on the Australian government to join its allies such as Canada, Netherlands, Japan, Spain and Belgium to impose trade and arm sanctions on Israel and to pressure Israel to end its ongoing genocide in Gaza.
We therefore ask the House to impose trade and arms sanctions on Israel until the blockade of food, fuel, electricity and water on Gaza ends and aid can freely enter Gaza.
from 5,509 citizens (Petition No. EN6141)
Banking and Financial Services

We are living through a cost of living crisis, at the same time businesses of all types and sizes are choosing to accept payment for goods and services by card payment only. At the point of sale the customer is charged the cost of the item as well as having the bank processing fee passed on to the customer by the card payment system. This is unfair on the customer and is adding to the real price gouging of items. As our banks have reported multi billion dollar profits in recent months they should be forced by Act of Parliament to absorb card payment costs or be banned from charging these fees.

We therefore ask the House to legislate that all banks and financiers either be required to absorb all card processing fees or be prevented from charging card processing fees to customers at point of sale.
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN6142)
Cybersafety
Advocacy and action to restrict 13 & 14 year olds from opening accounts across all social media applications.
We are advocating for legislative change due to the ongoing issues that social media presents for our teens.

At present children can be 13 and above with parental approval in the social media landscape and it is affecting their mental health and development with the array of heavy world affairs, sensitive content and misinformation, the cyber bulling and scamming, as well as potential risks such as paedophilia, potential grooming and sex trafficking as predators have mastered the art of disguising themselves and luring children into their web, and sites such as Instagram and Tik Tok are popular hunting grounds. Especially for 13 and 14 year olds whom are extremely vulnerable.
The data is also suggesting the affect on teen mental health has been astronomical.
We therefore ask the House to
a) adopt past due legislative and regulatory change in laws that restrict children up to age fifteen (15) from opening a social media account.
b) that regardless of parental approval the federal government makes it unlawful for children up to age fifteen (15) from opening a social media account.
c) That meta and other social media companies are held to codes of lawful practises for enabling account activations to children up to age fifteen (15).
d) that age restrictions of up to age fifteen (15) are legislated in consistencies in line with mature age television and movie screening guidelines.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN6145)
Taha, Mr Muhammad

Muhammad Taha is one of the heros from the Bondi attack who risked his life to save others. He was stabbed in the stomach and suffers from major injuries due to his heroism and motive to save lives. Taha desrves to be recognised as an Australian citizen the same way
Damien Guerot was for his brave acts. Muhammad Taha has not been offered citizenship however Damien Guerot even though they both displayed extraordinary bravery during the attacks.
We therefore ask the House to offer Muhammad Taha citizenship and recognise him as a brave hero during the Bondi attacks.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN6147)
Law Enforcement

Currently pending charges appear on nationally coordinated police checks. This is, by its very nature, prejudicial. The backbone of our legal system is that any given person is presumed innocent until proven otherwise, beyond any shadow of a doubt. Having pending charges on a police check is prohibitive of gaining employment. The court system is extremely backlogged, with estimations of trial dates being given a year or more ahead of time means that an accused that is released on bail, for the entire time they are on bail are unable to, or extremely unlikely to be offered a job if that employer asks for a police check during the recruitment process, which is about 95% of job offerings. Not being able to work and support oneself while going through what is likely one of the most harrowing experiences an individual can have, has catastrophic and often tragic results. An accused that has been released on bail, has already been deemed by a magistrate to not be a threat to the public by the very virtue of being granted bail in the first place. We claim that an accused individual is presumed innocent, so why are we punishing individuals that have not been found guilty of committing a crime and are innocent according to law? A pending charge is not a conviction. A pending charge does not mean guilt. A pending charge welcomes discrimination.
We therefore ask the House to take action and have pending charges omitted from police checks.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6148)
Veterans
We, the undersigned, petition the Parliament of Australia to address the urgent and dire conditions faced by Australian Defence Force (ADF) veterans.

ADF veterans encounter significant challenges upon returning to civilian life, including homelessness, high rates of suicide, and protracted battles to have injuries recognised for treatment and compensation. Unlike civilian counterparts, the military lacks a comprehensive work cover system, leaving veterans vulnerable upon discharge.

Moreover, the process of accessing medical support post-discharge is excessively bureaucratic and time-consuming, with veterans waiting up to three years to be accepted for white or gold cards. These cards, designed for medical treatment costs, merely serve as a gateway to further assessments for medical compensation, prolonging veterans' suffering and exacerbating mental health issues.

We therefore ask the House to take decisive action to alleviate the burdens faced by ADF veterans by abolishing the white and gold card system altogether. Instead, we advocate for free access to medical care for veterans as a fundamental right for their service to the nation.

By removing financial barriers to medical treatment, veterans can receive timely and comprehensive care, thereby improving their overall well-being and reducing the mental health toll imposed by navigating bureaucratic obstacles for essential services.
We call upon the Parliament to prioritise the welfare of our ADF veterans by implementing this critical reform without delay.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN6151)
Freedom of Speech

The powers of the eSafety Commission, conferred by the Online Safety Act 2021, are so broad as to threaten Australian democracy and the liberty of all Australians. Democracy cannot function without free expression, including the right to speak, be heard, and to seek out information unimpeded. The eSafety Commission's powers can and have been used to interfere with that critical democratic function.

It does not take a tyrant to remove the liberty of a people, only a small group of well-meaning people committed to the righteousness of their cause. The eSafety Commission's powers are vulnerable to influence by such a group. Arguably, they already have been, with criticism of transgenderism being suppressed on multiple occasions on order of the eSafety Commission. What else has been suppressed?

The powers of the eSafety Commission are so broad as to be vulnerable to ideological capture by a small but fervent minority. This is unacceptable. The risk of a harm to all Australians, present and future, by restricting free expression must be balanced against the risk of local harm to individuals from objectionable or even harmful speech. The Online Safety Act 2021 and the powers conferred on the eSafety Commission do not acceptably balance those risks.

We therefore ask the House to repeal the Online Safety Act 2021 and limit the power of the Australian government to restrict Australian's free expression, including the right to speak, be heard, and seek out information unimpeded, in order to safeguard Australian democracy and the liberty of all Australians.
from 75 citizens (Petition No. EN6152)
Queensland Air Museum
In 2019, along with other heritage organisations, QAM submitted an
Expression of Interest to Defence to be allocated an F/A-18 'Classic'
Hornet. We recently became aware that 8 aircraft have been delivered to 7
other heritage organisations, with the remaining 41 aircraft destined for
destruction.
Despite repeated requests to the Minister, we remain unaware of the reasons
why Australia's largest air museum has not been allocated a Hornet, why
Queensland was the only state with an air museum to be denied an
allocation and why we were not advised of the decision at the time.
The Queensland Air Museum (QAM), located in Caloundra, is Australia's
largest aviation museum and a major tourist attraction. Open 363 days a year, it is home to a
diverse collection of over 80 historic military and civilian aircraft, a large
display of aero engines and an extensive range of rare Australian aviation
artifacts. QAM is sustained by a workforce of 150 volunteers who participate in a
wide range of activities from museum management and administration to
complex aircraft restoration and maintenance.
We therefore ask the House to request the Minister for Defence to
direct his Department to allocate one of the remaining F/A-18 'Classic'
Hornet aircraft scheduled for destruction to the Queensland Air Museum for
preservation and display.
from 2,434 citizens (Petition No. EN6153)
Tertiary Education: Mandatory Work Placement
To the Education Minister Jason Chalmers,
I am writing to you about a social issue that requires immediate attention.

I ask the Education Minster Jason Chalmers to heed the call from us as students with the recommendation that funding be allocated to support currently unpaid work placements moving towards a paid placement model.
I request this recommendation be given due attention and for the funding allocation for this social issue to become part of the new 2024 Federal Budget.

As a student, I am currently studying at the Ourimbah campus of the University of Newcastle, and as social work students we are required to complete two work placements totalling 1,000 hours of unpaid work. The work that I contribute for the betterment of our society feels devalued when it is unpaid. Also, this places me under financial stress of not being able to meet my monthly financial obligations. This has contributed to the dropout rate that is increasing among us as students. Social Work and Community Services are essential services that are beneficial to our society, we call for social justice and a right to be paid for our work contribution.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Allocate funding to organisations that provide for our student placements, to make it possible for them to pay us the minimum industry standard of pay.
2. Legislate standards into practice that ensure mandatory payment by education organisations of student work during placement.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6154)
Mental Health
Due to the ongoing crisis of mental health and lack of services available to all Australians and the ongoing community violence that has been escalating for a number of years .

We therefore ask the House to provide free mental health services to all Australians and an improved diagnosis and assessment system available for people with intervention and unlimited support in their recovery.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN6156)
Mental Health

Access to mental health care is a fundamental human right that financial barriers should not constrain. However, the prevalence of gap fees in psychology services creates a divide, leaving many individuals unable to access evidence-supported treatments for their mental health needs. By ensuring equitable access to evidence-supported therapies, we can offer hope, healing, and support to those in need. Let's advocate for a system that prioritises mental health equity and removes financial barriers that hinder individuals from seeking the support they deserve.

We therefore ask the House to Investigate and call upon Policymakers and Health Authorities to prioritise the removal or reduction of gap fees in psychology services. By ensuring accessible and affordable mental health care based on evidence-supported treatments, we can enhance the well-being of individuals and families facing mental health challenges. It is crucial to make evidence-based therapies accessible to all, irrespective of financial circumstances. Let's work together to establish a system that values mental health equity and supports those in need. Join us in advocating for the elimination of financial barriers to mental health care and promoting evidence-supported therapies as the standard of care for all individuals seeking mental wellness.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN6157)
Banking and Financial Services

Business going cashless is hurting society. You go to pay rent or bills or buy food or fuel for a vehicle to go to appointments. The businesses have a blackout you can't pay . You will be late or miss an important appointment . If internet gets hacked it might shut banks or anything down for days. You can't pay anything. We as a society do embrace technology but not if it isn't reliable . Until you can walk into any businesses and pay without fear of a blackout or being hacked. We should not go cashless.
We therefore ask the House to Intervene in this and ask all businesses to accept cash and not go cashless.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN6158)
Climate Change

We call upon the Australian government to establish an Australian Climate Corps, modelled after the recently launched American Climate Corps initiative in the United States. This program would mobilise everyone to combat climate change through conservation, clean energy, and community resilience projects.

As a nation already grappling with the effects of climate change, such as prolonged droughts, catastrophic bushfires, and the bleaching of the Great Barrier Reef, Australia must take decisive action to mitigate and adapt to this global crisis. An Australian Climate Corps would provide paid opportunities for all Australians to gain valuable skills and experience in climate-related fields, while simultaneously contributing to the nation's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and build resilience in our communities.
Participants in the Australian Climate Corps could work on projects such as:
Protecting and restoring Australia's unique ecosystems and biodiversity
Deploying clean energy solutions and improving energy efficiency in homes and public buildings.
Assisting communities in preparing for and recovering from extreme weather events
Promoting sustainable agriculture and enhancing food security.
Engaging in community outreach and education to raise awareness about climate change and sustainable practices

By investing in an Australian Climate Corps, the government would not only create meaningful employment opportunities for young people but also demonstrate its commitment to addressing the urgent threat of climate change. This initiative would foster a new generation of climate leaders and contribute to a more sustainable and resilient future for all Australians.
We therefore ask the House to establish an Australian Climate Corps
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN6160)
Artificial Intelligence
We urge the Australian government to establish a dedicated fund and programme to advance the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in our nation.
As AI revolutionises industries and societies worldwide, Australia must take a proactive approach in leading the way.

To ensure success, we must invest in local AI research and development and attract the brightest minds from top universities worldwide. Implementing policies that enable high-skilled immigration for AI experts will make Australia a global hub for AI innovation, benefiting from diverse knowledge and expertise.

A well-structured fund and programme, combined with a welcoming environment for international AI experts, will enable collaboration and drive groundbreaking advancements. This approach will ensure Australia remains competitive globally while fostering economic growth and job creation.
By prioritising AI development, Australia can set a global standard for creating AI systems that serve the interests of all Australians.

Establishing this fund and programme, along with policies that attract top AI talent, is critical to securing Australia's future as an AI leader. We call upon the government to position Australia at the forefront of the AI revolution.
We therefore ask the House to establish a dedicated fund and programme to advance the development of Artificial Intelligence
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6161)
Disability Services

60 Minutes bought to light the horrendous acts happening within our disability community. It is a truly devastating event and the people responsible for treating Lee Anne and so many others get off so lightly with such disgusting treatment of a human being. The 3 women who were caught on camera deliberately abusing a person with disabilities got off far too lightly, a small fine and the others had to apologies and donate to a charity. We need to help our vulnerable community have a voice, and take a firm stance with harsh penalties to help top violence against the disability community and to deter others from doing the same thing.

We therefore ask the House to take a firm stance against violence to people with disabilities. With harsher penalties, criminal charges and banning them for life from ever working within the industry again.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN6162)
Nuclear Energy

To get Australians the benefits of the Australian government and international funding of businesses and their retention of investment and technology development in the international fusion energy industry on Australian shores. The goal is to secure licenses, develop Fusion energy, and establish demonstration fusion power plants in Australia, allowing active involvement in the expanding international industry and maintaining and grow Australia's standing in the South East Asian region.

We therefore ask the House to swiftly consider funding and implementing research and development into fusion power. Maritime and space propulsion in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution not only addresses future climate concerns and enhances energy security but also holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation involving experts and the public to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing our nation's cleaner, more resilient energy landscape.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6163)
Nuclear Energy: Maritime Industry

To get the Australian maritime and shipping industry, the benefits of the Australian government and international funding of businesses and their retention of investment and technology development in the international maritime fusion energy industry in Australian waters and on Australian shores. The objective is to obtain licenses for maritime fusion energy in Australia, progress its development, and set up demonstration maritime propulsion to showcase its commercial potential. This will allow Australia to join the global expansion of this industry.

We therefore ask the House to consider funding swiftly and implementing research and development into maritime fusion propulsion in Australian waters and onshore. Embracing this low-carbon solution addresses future climate concerns and enhances energy security and holds the potential for economic growth, maritime trade security, and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation involving experts and the public to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing our nation's cleaner, more resilient energy landscape.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6164)
Nuclear Energy: Space Industry

The Australian government should provide more funding to benefit the infant space industry in Australia and encourage the retention of investment and technology development in the international space propulsion and space colonisation power systems using the developing international fusion energy sector on Australian soil and skies. Getting licencing off and developing Fusion energy in Australia and building demonstration fusion power plants to show commercial viability so Australia can participate further in the international space industry.

We therefore ask the House to consider funding and implementing research and development into space fusion propulsion systems and space settlement power systems in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution addresses future climate and space concerns, enhances energy security and space and air security, and holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation involving experts and the public to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing our nation's cleaner, more resilient energy landscape.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6165)
Nuclear Energy

To get Australians the benefits of the Australian government and international funding of businesses and their retention of investment and technology development in the international Aneutronic fusion energy industry on Australian shores. Getting licencing and developing Fusion energy in Australia and building an Aneutronic fusion demonstration fusion power plant to show commercial viability so Australia can participate in this international growth industry.

We therefore ask the House to swiftly consider funding and implementing research and development into Aneutronic fusion power in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution not only addresses future climate concerns and enhances energy security but also holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation involving experts and the public to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing our nation's cleaner, more resilient energy landscape and bringing back HB11 to Australia.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6166)
Cybersafety
Affecting the mental health of our youth,
Exposure to high levels of unnecessary content
We therefore ask the House to consider the ban of or serious changes in social media for under 16
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6168)
Freedom of Speech

The Australian constitution does not at this time have written anywhere in its entirety a citizens right to freedom of speech or a citizen's right to freedom of the press . Australians citizens deserve the right to these particular freedoms and the mentioned freedoms must be enshrined in the Australian constitution. The governments elected by the Australian people should not have the right to censor the press or dictate the speech of Australian citizens in any manner ! Freedom of Speech must be the basis of the Australian culture! It is the most simple yet powerful of all freedoms and Australians must be allowed it.
We therefore ask the House to by all means necessary apply Freedom of Speech and Freedom of the Press into the Australian Constitution
from 249 citizens (Petition No. EN6169)
National Security

We, concerned Australian citizens, urge the House of Representatives to act decisively against Australians who have served in the Hamas military wing, Al-Qassam Brigades, or Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) and are suspected of war crimes. Upon their return, we request immediate arrest and a thorough investigation into their actions.
We therefore ask the House to to:
1. Arrest and detain any returnees from the Al-Qassam Brigades or IDF where there's a reasonable suspicion of war crime involvement.
2. Conduct impartial, thorough investigations into these allegations, in line with Australia's international obligations.
3. Restrict movement within Australia of suspects until their legal cases are resolved, upholding the integrity of our laws and international justice.
4. Work with international bodies and use all legal avenues to prosecute these individuals.
5. Ensure transparency about these proceedings and outcomes with the Australian public.
We expect the House to prevent Australia from becoming a refuge for those who may have committed atrocities abroad, affirming our commitment to global human rights.
from 206 citizens (Petition No. EN6170)
Middle East

In response to breaches of international law, this petition urges the Australian House of Representatives to apply consistent measures by sanctioning Israeli officials and entities involved in actions in Gaza and illegal settlements, similarly to measures against Russia.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Initiate sanctions and asset freezes against Israeli officials and military leaders involved in Gaza and the West Bank.
2. Apply sanctions to businesses within illegal Israeli settlements.
3. Extend asset freezes to residents of these settlements.
4. Align Australia's foreign policy with global sanctions norms.
5. Ensure transparent enforcement of these sanctions.
This alignment underscores Australia's commitment to international law and human rights.
from 552 citizens (Petition No. EN6171)
Universities
The current annual increase of HECS debt is far too high.
According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics the Median salary for Australian is 1,953.70 per week as of November 2023
With current indexing if someone has a HECS debt with $70k (which is just over half the limit of $121,844), it would be effectively impossible to pay off this debt
This is not sustainable financially nor politically, as it disincentives people study and places unnecessary financial strain on the youth who are already struggling with a housing crisis
We therefore ask the House to lower the rate to an extent to which Australians can feasibly pay it off in a lifetime
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN6172)
Occupied Palestinian Territories

Australia's foreign minister Penny Wong has recently said that Canberra would consider recognition of a Palestinian state. However, there is no visible progress with the cause. The World is watching a genocide unfolding in plain sight. Our screens are flooded with the images and videos of murdered, mutilated, starved people of Palestine. The world is also very well aware who are behind these massacres and ethnic cleansing.
Currently, 139 out of 193 UN member states recognize the state of Palestine.
On 18 April 2024, 12 countries out of members of the UN SC gave their vote in favor of the state of Palestine.
If Australia believes in Democracy, its high time to demonstrate its democratic value in the court of the World and stand on the right side of the history.
As Penny Wong said, a secured and stable Palestinian state is they key to the stability in the region and the world.
We therefore ask the House to take necessary measures to declare the recognition of the state of Palestine.
from 129,813 citizens (Petition No. EN6173)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products

The new vaping laws have impacted honest Citizens who vape to cease smoking. The difficult process of accessing these products through pharmacies will result in citizens returning to cigarettes. The ban in claimed to reduce minors having access to vaping products and a presciption allows regulation on age limits when purchasing vaping products. The ban on personal importation of nicotine vaping products with a prescription should be lifted and only have quantity regulation in place of 200ml nicotine e-liquid per prescribed person on a monthly limit.

We therefore ask the House to lift the ban on personal importation of vaping products including nicotine e-liquid and have a regulation on quantity instead. The proposed quantity limit is 200ml nicotine e-liquid per person with a prescription with a monthly limit in place to reduce risk of resale. The 200ml limit can be broken up into smaller individual containers but not exceed 200ml total liquid.
from 304 citizens (Petition No. EN6174)
Migration
Kiwis and Australians have strong ties and should be allowed to stay in Australia. There should be rehabilitation and help for people not to just kick them out when they have loved ones here.
We therefore ask the House to that kiwis deported be able to return back to Australia in at least 5 years time. It should never be a permanent ban.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6175)
Migration

Anyone with Australian partner should be able to return to Australia. As a citizen and in a family that have been in Australia over 100 years I believe we should have the choice to have our loved ones here. My partner got deported back to NZ and because this it has caused a tremendous amount of pain and suffering. I am unable to stay in NZ permanently due financial crisis and family members needing me in Australia. This has caused a lot of financial stress being in NZ every year for 5 years going back and forth. I feel that we have stayed strong so long and there should have been rehabilitation provided he has now changed his life for the better but is still denied Access here.
We therefore ask the House to bring 501s back that have Australian partners
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6176)
Taxation
Australian Government to stop the Taxing of Middle to Low income Australia, and start Taxing multi million dollar corporations.

We therefore ask the House to consider Taxing multi million dollar corporations more. While reducing the Tax middle to lower income Australians have to pay. And put forward policy that would prevent corporations from increasing their prices without government approval.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN6177)
Health Care

Normacol Plus was suddenly discontinued in 2023. It was an off-the shelf pharmaceutical product that was very useful for a group of patients with decreased rectal sensitivity, slow bowel transit and increased gut sensitivity. It is very different to other laxatives as it has dual functions (bulking agent and stimulant) and it is also in the low FODMAP group which means it is suitable for most patients with a sensitive gut and food intolerance.
Unfortunately, there is no other single pharmaceutical product in the market that can completely replace this unique product at this time.

We therefore ask the House to liaise with Norgine Australia to ascertain whether they would give due consideration to re-introduce Normacol Plus to Australia. This was a very important pharmaceutical product for our patient group and since its withdrawal, it has caused much distress and anxiety to our patient group. To gut-focused specialists and health professionals, Normacol Plus was considered to be an important pharmaceutical product, like any other medication in Australia. We cannot discontinue a drug, such as a diabetic or blood thinning drug, without providing a suitable replacement.
Bringing Normacol Plus back will help to:
• decrease hospital admissions and emergency presentations with abdominal pain
• decrease people with irritable bowel syndrome getting sick leave from work

• decrease economical strain on Medicare support for chronic illness such as constipation, abdominal and pelvic pain, faecal urgency, faecal incontinence, haemorrhoids, rectal bleeding, psychological illness associated with bowel problems, etc.
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN6178)
National Parks
The natural land of Australia belongs to all of us.
Stop the government making decisions on our behalf, to close parts of our national parks.
Places like Lake Eyre and Horizontal Falls belong to Australia as a whole.
Any decisions that closes parts of Australia off to the public, should be decided by all Australian as a whole.
We all have the right to enjoy them and we all have the right to access them.
And we most certainly all have the right to collectively decide if they should be shut.
We therefore ask the House to cease the locking down of any parts of Australia's natural land, unless a unanimous decision has been made by Australian as a whole.
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN6179)
Defence

New Chief of Defence David Johnston has a task ahead to restore the confidence of all Australians, as we have become a tool of American capitalist dominance at the cost of our own self determination. The 2022 move to develop nuclear weapon storage facilities is a move toward NATO style degradation of diplomacy that pits Australia against its most significant diplomatic and trading partners for the benefit of American economy and is an abuse of the Non-proliferation of Nuclear weapons Treaty. US trade and defence deals are shrouded in secrecy and are undermining Australia's ability of self determination. in 2019, Trump scrapped the TPP, then the US/China Trade deal allowed China to be blamed for transferring barley, wine and fresh produce to USA from other importers (ie Australia). Admiral Reid recently highlighted Australia will not be responsible for the operation of AUKUS submarines, nor is Australian manufacture part of current agreements. America's recent non-diplomacy, supporting prolonged IDF onslaught to enable trade from India through Pakistan to Israeli ports has been an alerting example of this diplomatic decay. Australia does have an interest in the welfare and well being of American citizens, but not at the cost of our own self determination, as this is the cascade effect of storing nuclear weapons. This has been raised in petitions since 2010, but this year, has become critically crystal clear.
We therefore ask the House to repeal force posture agreement plans and actions to store or cycle nuclear weapons in or through Australia.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN6180)
Disability Support Pension
APPLY VERTIGO AND MENIERES DISEASE TO SOCIAL SECURITY DSP LIST AND MEDICARE
The symptoms include:
Frequent recurring episodes of vertigo lasting between 20 minutes to few hours
Nausea and vomiting due to severe vertigo
Loss of balance
Fluctuating or progressive loss of hearing, ultimately leading to permanent loss of hearing
Ringing in the ear (tinnitus)
Feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear
Complications are primarily attributed to vertigo and hearing loss, and include:
Fatigue
Emotional stress
Anxiety and depression
Increased risk of falls due to vertigo
Inability to drive vehicles or operate heavy machinery
All these symptoms are on the medical list to be examined by a medical practitioner from 20 points, YET many sufferers are being denied DSP .
If sufferers are on medication long term of over a year which is not subsidized by Medicare then the sufferer should be declared to have a disability and be accepted DSP by Centrelink
We therefore ask the House to add specifically vertigo and Meniere's disease to the list for DSP Centrelink
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN6182)
Law Enforcement
In these tense times, ensuring every Australian lives in a secure environment is of great importance. In order that Australia is kept secure we propose:
Violence Reduction: Fund community-based prevention programs.
Strict Gun Safety: Introduce thorough background checks for all gun purchases and establish a national gun registry for better tracking.

Community and Law Enforcement Collaboration: Foster cooperation between law enforcement and communities to enhance trust and improve public safety. Ensure law enforcement are given sufficient tools and training in de-escalation and community relations.
Public Awareness: Launch national campaigns on safety practices, the importance of reporting suspicious activities, and emergency response.
We call on our leaders to prioritise these measures for the safety of all Australians.
We therefore ask the House to ensure every Australian lives in a secure environment.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6183)

subdebateinfo.title: Coffs Harbour Jetty Foreshore Precinct Revitalisation Project

p.span: Coffs Harbour Jetty Foreshore Precinct Revitalisation Project

I believe the dept of NSW Property & Development has been reckless & incompetent in the design, planning of the Masterplan process for the Coffs Harbour Jetty Foreshore Precinct Revitalisation Project, in not considering light rail, extending Howard St to Jordan Esplanade, removing a level crossing on Marina Drive & re-diverting a heavy rail line south/west of Coffs. We need a more strategic planning process at the state & national level to resolve the transport problems in & around Coffs Harbour & uban planning to benefit the whole North Coast.

We therefore ask the House to investigate & take over planning & funding for the Coffs Harbour Jetty Foreshore Project to incorporate a new light rail between Lyons Rd, Sawtell & Shepherds Lane, Coffs Harbour, to remove the existing level crossing on Marina Drive, divert the existing heavy rail line south/west of Coffs with a new rail station at Toormina Gardens Shopping Centre or the Coffs Base Hospital & finally extend Howard St to cross the railway to connect with Jordan Esplanade. This project is too important to leave to state planners. Federal funding needs to be made available to carry out the works identified as the NSW Govt will miss the opportunity to develop Coffs for the 21st Century.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6186)
Information Technology: Equipment Standards
Prevalent practices of printer manufacturers include:
disabling scanning until print cartridges are replaced or even permanently disabling scanning when non-genuine cartridges are installed;
disabling black and white printing when a colour cartridge is empty;
disabling the use of 3rd party cartridges and disabling the use of genuine cartridges that they deem to have expired.

These practices are intended to increase ink and toner sales, but result in unnecessary e-waste and are detrimental to the consumer. These hidden restrictions are difficult to discover during the purchase decision making process, moreover, some manufacturers only introduce these restrictions later, after sale, by firmware updates. Conscientious printer manufacturers are forced to compete with the unscrupulous manufacturers that engage in these practices.
We therefore ask the House to address this issue by introducing the following mandatory requirements for all printers sold in Australia:
1) Multi-function devices may not block functions like scanning when unrelated consumables are empty or when non-genuine cartridges are installed.
2) Printers may not block monochrome printing when only colour cartridges are empty.
3) Printers may not block third-party or expired toner cartridges (but voiding warranty is reasonable).

By enacting legislation to address these issues, the House of Representatives can promote sustainability and responsible consumption in the printing industry, ultimately reducing e-waste and its environmental impacts and, benefit the consumer and level the playing field for conscientious manufacturers.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN6187)
Australian Federal Police
Currently, AFP police officers are the lowest base paid police officers in the country.
If you factor in allowances, they are the third worst paid police officers in the country.
This isn't good enough for Australia's premier law enforcement agency, which protects the country and its many communities.

We therefore ask the House to recognise the excellent work of Australian Federal Police officers and commit to the principles of 'same job, same pay' by providing additional funding to the AFP to increase allowances and wages to ensure that AFP officers aren't the lowest base paid police officers in the country.
from 3,674 citizens (Petition No. EN6189)
Family Law

Currently, the lack of mandatory DNA testing can lead to situations where individuals are wrongly assigned financial obligations for children who are not biologically theirs. This not only results in financial hardship but also undermines the well-being of the child involved.

By requiring DNA testing as a standard procedure in child support cases, we can prevent unjust outcomes and uphold the rights of both parents and children. Additionally, accurate paternity determination is crucial for maintaining trust and integrity within the legal system.

We therefore ask the House to sider supporting and co-sponsoring legislation that mandates DNA testing for child support claims. This initiative will help ensure that child support arrangements are based on factual evidence, leading to fairer outcomes for all parties involved.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN6190)
Personal Information and Privacy

This petition is to ask the government to bring in stronger individual protections and a better right to privacy and the right to your own image. As it stands Australia has no law protecting individuals using your image without consent, which can and has lead to false accusations of crimes and the spreading of harmful or misleading information.

We therefore ask the House to develop a right to your own identity law that follows the EU standard and that portraits of persons may only be published and circulated with the prior consent of the person depicted—regardless of whether it is a portrait photograph of a single person or a street scene involving several people. The recognisability can be based on realistically visible physical features (face, hair colour or even posture). However, it is also sufficient that conclusions about the identity of the person depicted can be drawn solely from the accompanying caption or from the objects shown in the photo (house, car, accessories, etc.).
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6191)
Kidney Disease

Haemodialysis patients that dialyse at home are virtually chained to their home because of having to dialyse at least 3 days per week. Holidays are difficult because of the time consuming process of making hospital bookings for the trip. After 3-4 months organising, often we have to cancel or rearrange the trip. If portable machines are available, then holidays can be more spontaneous, money will be saved on in hospital dialysis and hospital beds will be freed up.
We therefore ask the House to consider financing the return of portable haemodialysis machines to public hospitals. This will enable home haemodialysis patients to live a more natural life.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6192)

subdebateinfo.title: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

p.span: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

The Federal Government continues to ignore the requests of survivors and the advice of those on the frontline supporting women and children to remain safe. Our National Plan is not working and the rates of FDV homicide, rates of sexual violence and drivers of domestic and gendered violence are clearly not understood by Government.

We demand a National Royal Commission into the drivers of gendered violence, including the abject failure to see children as victims of domestic abuse and a focus on perpetrator consequences, accountability, rehabilitation and prevention. We know on average one perpetrator has up to five victims.
We do not call for a National Royal Commission at the expense of the immediate priority or need to invest in keeping women and children safe. We can do both of these things.
Our ask comes directly from survivors of family violence and victims of family violence homicide.

We therefore ask the House to commit to a National Royal Commission to better understand the drivers of men's violence against women. We ask the Federal Government to be accountable in their commitment to women by providing the most comprehensive, in depth and holistic review ever undertaken in Australia.
Victims of institutional abuse, of banks and of Robodebt schemes have been vindicated, supported and had systems changed in the wake of their experiences through a Royal Commission.
It is absurd that we have never undertaken a comprehensive review of gendered violence and all that contributes to it at a National Level.
from 2,648 citizens (Petition No. EN6193)
Taxation

The 6 monthly, inflation linked excise rises on fuel and alcohol artificially inflates the price of described goods and is itself inflationary. Furthermore, when there is a period of negative inflation, the excise does not decrease in line with the negative inflation. The 6 monthly excise rise on alcohol in particular has an extremely detrimental effect on small craft breweries, and the live music industry. The excise rises are independent of the actual price of the goods themselves and are based on the overall inflation rate of the economy, resulting in the excise as a percentage of the goods gradually increasing over time.
We therefore ask the House to remove the 6 monthly excise rises linked to inflation and replace with a flat percentage rate of tax for said goods.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN6197)
International Students
The proposed government laws, which will take effect on July 1, 2024, will exclude all international students studying in Australia who are over 35 from being able to apply for the 485 graduate visa.

This will cause serious financial and emotional harm to thousands of international students who are already in Australia studying, expecting they will have access to a working visa when they finish their studies.

Many students have planned and counted on gaining this postgraduate working visa for many varied reasons. For many, it is an essential requirement to gain their skill assessments for migration purposes, for others who need Australian work experience to gain specific licences, and for others who depend on gaining meaningful Australian work experience.
This is not the right way to treat our international visitors who contribute significantly to our economy.

These law changes will not only crush the dreams and hopes of the people we wanted to attract to Australia. It also creates a reputation for Australia that you cannot trust what the Australian government offers to international students.
In particular, this law impacts highly talented PhD students, most of whom are over 35.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a transition period for these laws to take effect. Those international students who had already arrived and began their courses in Australia before the announcement should be allowed to apply for the Graduate 485 up to the age of 50. Whenever their course is completed, this transition arrangement should remain in effect.
from 21,298 citizens (Petition No. EN6198)
Telecommunications
Residents disturbed by flight radiation during curfew.
• Constant radiation affects our ability to rest/recharge to deal with constant 5G upgrades
• Flight radiation overlaps/enhances 5G radiation, causing health issues.
• SA government needs to prioritise civilians' well-being.
We therefore ask the House to Return to No-flights during Curfew in SA and back off on the 5G radiation upgrades. Nerves are not coping.
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN6199)
Health Care

Admitting into Mental Health Care requires a session of Psychiatrist appointments with compulsory medication for usually 6mths. As a Inpatient or MBU it is compulsory checked under tongues whilst breastfeeding and bottle feeding. Lots of these are new mental health patients that require counselling and psychiatric support.

Breastfeeding requires best fresh enzyme nutrition and calm environments. It also requires an alert responsive mother. If either parent is involved in SIDS they can be in jail. The mother is conformative and usually good at communicating however usually might ask for a lawyer in other circumstances.
Psychiatrists are good at supporting clients. The medication listed side effects out number the as calm listed.
We therefore ask the House to consolidate with Australian Hospital Management to ban medication whilst breastfeeding. That any inpatient supports educating the mothers in a non submissive mannerisms.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6201)
Tertiary Education: Mandatory Work Placement
Student teachers and nurses currently enrolled finishing their final practicum before July 1st 2025 will receive $0 in compensation for 600-1000 hours of unpaid work in a cost of living crisis.

We therefore ask the House to begin paying student teachers and nurses for their practium effective immediately. Or to provide back pay for all currently enrolled teaching and nursing students on July 1st 2025.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN6206)
Tertiary Education: Mandatory Work Placement
The government has recently made movements towards paying students for their clinical placements in order to ease financial stress.
Physiotherapists and occupational therapists have not been included in this funding despite having equal or larger hours of clinical placement than student groups receiving support.
In some instances they are required to commute and stay in rural areas for placements removing all ability to earn an income during this time.
With the growing cost of living and rental crisis these terms are resulting in a greater drop out rate or students unable to complete placements due to not being able to support themselves.

We therefore ask the House to include physiotherapy and occupational therapy students in the new grant scheme by the government, and pay these students for clinical placements in order to provide relief.
from 258 citizens (Petition No. EN6207)
Mental Health

We need to do more to save our children! Bring back mandatory rehabilitation for mentally ill and substance-addicted youths! A safe environment where they can work on their addictions, mental health problems and reengage with education.

There are homeless children with significant substance-abuse issues everywhere in Australia. We need to give the courts and hospitals the power to safely contain, detox and help these children with their drug and mental health problems. Currently the cycle continues long into adulthood and often results in the death of the young person, or even worse, the death of innocent bystanders.

Our courts NEED powers to make orders for mandatory residential drug treatment. There are so many young people nowadays that are damaged and vulnerable, they don't engage with voluntary programs, and therefore don't receive any treatment whatsoever.

As a community, we have an obligation to intervene as early as possible to help our young people. Build secure therapeutic residences and have credentialed clinicians and security personnel working there.

These facilities don't need to be the first resort for drug using children and teens, but where a child has had a chance to work with and engage in voluntary treatment first and for whatever reason they couldn't or wouldn't engage, we need to give health workers, teachers and police the capacity to nominate those individuals for involuntary long treatment programs.
We therefore ask the House to enact a new YOUTH MENTAL HEALTH ACT that will give the power to help these children to our courts.
from 545 citizens (Petition No. EN6209)
COVID-19: Vaccination

On the 8th of May, 2024, it was announced that the Astrazeneca COVID19 vaccine has been withdrawn globally due to it causing fatal blood clots and low platelet counts. Indeed, a new disease came into existence due to their vaccination, known as Vaccine-induced Immune Thrombotic Thrombocytopenia.
Many Australians, myself included, were coerced to take said vaccine, even though a majority of Australian's then went on to quickly come down with the disease they were vaccinated against.

It's not acceptable that in a supposedly free country, citizens would be coerced into taking something that could result in their death. This coercion came via threat of livelihood, inability to access service: Vacs, inability to see family members in nursing homes.

We were assured that these vaccines were safe and effective, yet we now know that they were neither. Those who refused such had their lives ruined, with bureaucrats encouraging isolation and stigmatisation of the unvaccinated. I still can't regain my former job in health care due to my vaccination status.

We therefore ask the House to 1: apologise for ever allowing mandates to occur. 2. Apologise for mandating a product which has now been globally withdrawn due to abovementioned risk of death. 3. Ensure that in a free country, informed consent free of coercion is reinforced for whatever the future holds.
The right to bodily autonomy is essential in a free society.
from 98 citizens (Petition No. EN6210)
Occupied Palestinian Territories

Palestines and the people of Palestine are being unjustly exterminated by Israel and the IDF. They need support of any kind, something Australia is giving, but can and should be giving more to help stave this slaughter of innocents.
We therefore ask the House to actively permit more funding and support towards the people and state of Palestine.
from 4,007 citizens (Petition No. EN6212)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present three ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
First Nations Australians
Dear Ms Templeman,
I write to you in regards to petition EN5070.

The 2024-25 Federal Budget redirected funding that was set aside for Regional Voice models to other priorities within the Indigenous Australians portfolio, in line with the outcome of the 2023 referendum.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of12 February 2024 of a petition for a ceasing of all activities related to solar radiation management and geoengineering (EN5667). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
The Australian Government is firmly committed to taking action on climate change.

The government has legislated targets to reduce Australia's emissions by 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and achieve net zero by 2050 and committed over $40 billion to decarbonising our domestic economy. Current emissions projections, based on implementation of policies such as the reformed Safeguard Mechanism and the expanded Capacity Investment Scheme show that Australia is in striking distance of the 2030 target. The government is also committed to transforming Australia's electricity system to achieve its goal of82 per cent renewables by 2030.
The government is also working with states and territories and industry on emissions reduction across the economy.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a trusted source of scientific advice, and its work continues to inform the government. The recent IPCC Sixth Assessment Report provides an update on the latest climate science, and options for mitigating and adapting to climate change. In this report, the IPCC concluded that all proposed forms of climate geoengineering are 'speculative technologies' (section 1.4.3 of www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg3/chapter/chapter-1/), and that there are no available technologies that could be used to affect the global climate (section 4.6.3 of www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/chapter/chapter-40.
The government's stance on climate geoengineering, including solar radiation management (SRM), is based on the best available science and commitment to international cooperation and leadership.

As a party to the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, Australia has agreed to restrict all climate geoengineering, including SRM, unless it is for small-scale scientific research or unless the risks and scientific basis are appropriately considered (Decision X/33, 2010).

Additionally, in October 2023, the government successfully secured a decision under the United Nations Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer for researchers to consider risks and uncertainties for the ozone layer in any scientific studies or assessments related to high-altitude climate geoengineering (stratospheric aerosol injection), where small particles are released high in the atmosphere to reduce solar radiation and warming (Decision XXXV/4, 2023). Under this decision, member countries will also be provided updates on developments in stratospheric aerosol injection to assist with understanding of the potential impacts of this technology on the ozone layer.

Currently, Australia does not have a specific domestic regulatory framework for geoengineering activities. There is however legislation at the national and state level that provides protection for the environment against unacceptable environmental impacts of all types of activities. This includes the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act I999 and the Great Barrier ReefMarine Park Act I975.

As part of the government's commitment to protecting the World Heritage-listed Great Barrier Reef, the government is currently funding one research project into SRM. Climate change is the biggest threat to the Reef, and many World Heritage sites globally. The Reef Restoration and Adaptation Program {RRAP) is investigating the use of marine cloud brightening, where salt from sea water is sprayed into the air to help form clouds, to prevent or reduce localised bleaching stress on coral reefs by reducing the amount of sunlight reaching the Reef. More information on this program is available on the RRAP website at gbrrestoration.org/program/ cooling-and-shading/.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Veterans: Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Ms Templeman,
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February2024 regarding petition EN5854.

I acknowledge a decision made by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) in 2023 in relation to a privacy complaint, and the recent withdrawal of ethics approval for the program, are relevant to those concerns.

Over the 19 years of the program, Veterans' MATES delivered 71 high quality health education modules across a wide range of veteran specific health issues, empowering veterans to better manage their health and supporting health practitioners to improve the care for veterans who use medicines and require health services and supports.
As you may know, on 9 February 2024, I directed the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) to close down the Veterans' Medicines Advice and Therapeutics Education Service· (Veterans' MATES) program.
This decision was made in acknowledgement of a period of increasing concerns in the veteran community about the use of DVA data and client personal information in the program.

I have asked DVA to actively examine options for possible future programs that provide similar health benefits to the veteran community, while also meeting community and stakeholder expectations around data use requirements.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): The petitions presented today cover a wide range of subject matters. Several petitions relate to the conflict in the Middle East, including one that gathered just under 130,000 signatures. Another petition, which received more than 21,000 signatures, relates to the changes to the maximum eligible age for applicants of temporary graduate visas. Some of the other topics covered in today's petitions include a request for a royal commission into family violence and three requests for the Commonwealth prac payment scheme to include additional student cohorts.
I'm pleased that citizens and residents of Australia continue to engage with the House through the petitioning system. I thank the House.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: National Housing and Homelessness Plan Bill 2024

p.span: National Housing and Homelessness Plan Bill 2024
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Tink.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms TINK (North Sydney) (10:03): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Australia is in the middle of a housing crisis, with the costs associated with finding and maintaining a home growing faster than wages. Rental vacancies are at all-time lows, with 169,000 households on public housing waiting lists and another 122,000 people experiencing homelessness. Meanwhile, projected housing supply remains low and growing numbers of individuals and families are sleeping on the street or in their cars or living in tents. I hear consistently from my community that housing challenges are literally keeping them awake at night.

It isn't just the ability to afford a home that is affecting people but the security of tenure, proximity to jobs and concerns about whether their children and elderly parents will have long-term appropriate housing. Older residents looking to downsize tell me that they're simply unable to find an affordable apartment in their community that would leave them with enough cash to live on. Perversely, this means younger families can't find the family homes they want as older Australians struggle to leave them. I hear from nurses, teachers and firefighters who are faced with the decision of whether to spend two-thirds of their income on rent or to commute over 30 kilometres each way every day.

I've heard from people experiencing homelessness and the threat of homelessness, from forced couch surfing to overcrowding, insecure housing and street homelessness. The messages are the same. In every circumstance, the conversations take my breath away. At its heart, the concept of a home is so much more than just shelter. It is security, self-expression, relationships and family. Every human being has a fundamental right to be able to live in a safe environment. The very idea of homeownership is embedded in the Australian culture, yet we're now seeing generations of Australians who, despite their best efforts and hard work, can only dream of achieving the cultural milestone of homeownership and for whom this rite of passage is a roll of the dice, increasingly dependent on family financial assistance. Australia's housing crisis, however, has been a long time in the making. It is a multidimensional and complex issue with diverse causes and broad effects. That is why a strong, ambitious, overarching framework is so sorely needed—one that gives coherence to the national initiatives delivered since the 2022 election and sets a road map for long-term housing reform. This bill does just that.

Before I speak to the specifics of the bill, I want to thank Senator Pocock and his team for leading this work. Senator Pocock is today introducing this same bill through the Senate, and I'm proud to join him in introducing it to the House of Representatives, for, more than any other time in our parliament's history, we must be prepared to set politics aside and work together, party with party, house with house, to truly turn the tide. I also thank the member for Indi, who is seconding the bill, for her fearless work in fighting for improved outcomes for regional Australians. Finally, I thank Professor Hal Paulson and Dr Chris Martin for their thoughtful leadership and tireless efforts to make Australian housing policy better. Together with a broad range of expert stakeholders and drafters, they have given life to this bill, which will improve the governance and accountability of national housing policy.

For, you see, this bill sets out processes to develop, implement and maintain a national housing and homelessness plan aimed at facilitating a human rights based approach to housing. It draws inspiration from Canada's National Housing Strategy Act of 2019, which recognises housing as a fundamental human right. And it is founded on Australia's international obligations to realise the human right to adequate housing and uses the Commonwealth government's constitutional authority on external affairs to pursue this obligation. Importantly, while this bill sets out objectives and goals for the plan, it deliberately does not prescribe specific policies and programs. Rather, the government of the day would be responsible for its own plan, but the housing minister under this bill would be required to periodically report to parliament on progress and to revise and renew their plan as appropriate.

The bill also establishes the National Housing Consumer Council to ensure the perspectives of both tenants and homebuyers are provided directly to the housing minister, alongside the expert perspectives of the National Housing Supply and Affordability Council. It also establishes the National Housing and Homelessness Advocate to report independently on systemic issues and the progress of the plan.

Importantly, this bill has strong support, with the proposal to legislate a national housing and homelessness plan recently backed by over a hundred individuals and organisations, including leading academics, industry experts, economists, peak bodies and advocates and both past and present politicians from across the spectrum. These individuals and organisations are working on the ground to help alleviate homelessness. They are the organisations that support domestic violence victims to find safe and secure housing. They are the academic institutions tasked with finding policy solutions to Australia's housing crisis, and they are the human rights experts. And they all support the call for a legislated national housing and homelessness plan.

In closing, I want to recognise that the current government is striving to improve housing in this country and to thank them for that. But, to move forward in a consistent and constructive fashion, we must provide a collective understanding of the rules in this game, and we must put human rights at the centre of our ambitions. Earlier this year, I convened the North Sydney Community Housing Forum, a successful exercise in deliberative democracy that brought 30 ordinary people from across my community together to determine ways to improve housing affordability. The resounding message from that forum was, when it comes to housing policy, they want leadership, direction, long-term thinking and optimism. And that's what this bill does. It sets an overarching framework that I've heard my community wants. It provides a road map that puts human rights at the centre of all future federal housing policy, regardless of the government of the day, and it repositions homes from being seen as assets and returns them to their rightful location as homes where families grow and people age.
Today I call on the government to recognise this need and allow the bill to be brought to debate. I commend this bill to the House and cede the remainder of my time to the member for Indi.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?

Dr HAINES (Indi) (10:09): I rise to second the National Housing and Homelessness Plan Bill 2024. I do so with great pride to back the member for North Sydney and Senator Pocock on this extremely important legislation, which establishes that housing is a human right. That is not said often enough in this place. It's a right that all Australians, no matter their address, no matter their income, no matter their living situation, have somewhere to call home. It is absolutely fundamental to our dignity and to our physical and mental wellbeing.

As parliamentarians, we have a responsibility to do everything we can to ensure that all Australians have a place to call home, because the housing crisis gripping Australia and indeed much of the world is undermining so many people's right to an adequate standard of living. Across regional, rural and remote Australia people are struggling. Sky-high interest rates and declining rental availability are making it so hard for people to find a home. In my electorate of Indi, housing is more expensive and less accessible than at any other point in our lifetimes.

When I visit towns across my electorate I hear of people in townhouses being pushed into units. Those in units are being pushed into caravan parks, and those who were in the caravan parks are being pushed into tents alongside the rivers. Homelessness is at a level that I have not seen in the 35 years that I've lived in north-east Victoria. It's why I introduced my unlocking regional Australia housing bill in 2023, which would have ensured that a fair share of the government's investment in housing went to the regions. It's why I'm calling on this government to create a regional housing infrastructure fund to ensure that we can fund the critical enabling infrastructure that opens the land to allow houses to be built.

This government must do everything it can and use every tool at its disposal to address this crisis, and it's why I am proud to support this bill. Crucially, it will be recognised in legislation that housing is a human right and one that this parliament has an obligation to fulfil. The bill would also require the government of the day to prepare a national housing and homelessness plan to set out to the Australian people how it plans to ensure that everyone has somewhere to call home, somewhere to sleep at night and somewhere to be safe. Under this bill this plan would set out a 10-year road map to coordinate funding and program delivery across all levels of government. In a policy area as complex as housing, it is so important for the government to set a long-term strategic vision, irrespective of who is in government—and only the Commonwealth can provide that leadership.

A similar plan in Canada, which has a federal system just like ours, is already showing results in helping to coordinate action between different levels of government. As the member for North Sydney said, it is vital that we embed this plan in legislation to ensure no government can shirk its responsibilities to plan for a housing system that works for all of us. To establish the National Housing and Homelessness Plan in legislation would enhance its credibility. It would give us a yardstick by which to measure the government's performance. In addition, this bill would establish a national housing consumer council to ensure that the voices of those who live in their homes, the renters, the homebuyers, the retirees—the voices we never hear—are heard. The consumer council will ensure that their needs are reflected in policymaking.
This bill is common sense. We should recognise housing as a right. We should get on and do it, and we should do it now.
The SPEAKER: The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
NOTICES
Postponement

The SPEAKER (10:13): I inform the House that, pursuant to standing order 110, the honourable member for Mallee has postponed notice No. 2 standing in her name. The order of precedence of remaining private members' business notices, as determined by the Selection Committee's report adopted by the House on 5 June 2024, remains unchanged.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Environment
Dr SCAMPS (Mackellar) (10:14): I move:
That this House:

(1) notes that following the dire State of the Environment report released in 2021, the Government promised to act decisively to turn the tide in this country from nature destruction to nature repair;
(2) places on record its concern that:
(a) in December 2023, the Government legislated an expansion of the water trigger in the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act);
